parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies have directly compared the cost-effectiveness of different bracken control methods in shrublands.
[Statement 2]: Several methods have been evaluated for their effectiveness in controlling bracken.
[Statement 3]: One systematic review found that the herbicide asulam reduced bracken abundance if applied repeatedly.
[Statement 4]: Cutting may be equally effective as using herbicide for bracken control.
[Statement 5]: Herbicide application with asulam reduced bracken biomass or cover in some randomized, controlled studies.
[Statement 6]: Cutting has been shown to reduce bracken cover or biomass in some studies.
[Statement 7]: Neither cutting nor herbicide application was consistently effective across all studies.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found no effect on bracken abundance from either cutting or herbicide application.
[Statement 9]: Cutting followed by herbicide application has been shown to reduce bracken biomass or cover.
[Statement 10]: No studies have evaluated combinations of herbicide with grazing.
[Statement 11]: No studies have evaluated combinations of herbicide with seeding shrubland plants.
[Statement 12]: Bracken bruising has been found to increase bracken cover.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the most cost-effective method for controlling invasive bracken in shrublands?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the success rate of legally protecting specific plant species from gathering in shrublands?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There is no available evidence on the success rate of legally protecting specific plant species from gathering in shrublands.
[Statement 2]: Systematic searches of scientific journals and reports have not found any studies that directly evaluated the effectiveness of legally protecting specific plant species from gathering.
[Statement 3]: It is not possible to assess whether legal protection is effective or has any harmful impacts on plant species conservation in shrubland habitats.
[Statement 4]: The evidence base for the conservation intervention of legally protecting specific plant species from gathering remains completely unstudied.
